channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: „ÄêStop worrying about Go's error handling syntax„Äë‰∏çÂÜçÊãÖÂøÉGOÁöÑÈîôËØØÂ§ÑÁêÜËØ≠Ê≥ï
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã556 ‚Äî June 4, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

üñäÔ∏è I was meant to be travelling this week. My plans changed, but I‚Äôd already planned for a shorter issue, so it‚Äôs a quicker one this time. Back to full service next week!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

‚ÄúFor the foreseeable future, the Go team will stop pursuing syntactic language changes for error handling. We will also close all open and incoming proposals that concern themselves primarily with the syntax of error handling, without further investigation.‚Äù

___
Robert Griesemer and the Go team

[ On | No ] Syntactic Support for Error Handling ‚Äî The topic of handling errors in Go, and if it‚Äôs possible to improve the syntax around doing so, has been raised many times over the years, but sometimes it‚Äôs worth drawing a line under things and to focus elsewhere. Robert explains the matter, some of the proposals made over the years, and the benefits of maintaining the status¬†quo.

Robert Griesemer

The Guide to In-House Vs Managed Kubernetes-As-A-Service ‚Äî Struggling with the ‚Äúbuild vs. buy‚Äù decision when it comes to Kubernetes infrastructure management? You're not alone! Download the guide to discover the pros and cons of each approach as we break down the associated costs, risks & ROI. Get it¬†today!

Fairwinds sponsor

Pure vs. Impure Iterators in Go ‚Äî Go 1.23 introduced custom iterators, but the standard ‚Äòsingle-use‚Äô vs. not classification can be confusing. This post proposes a clearer pure vs. impure distinction, with concrete examples and performance¬†insights.

Julien Cretel

IN BRIEF:

  • Even if you don't need it, this JavaScript Developer's Guide to Go is a primer that might suit someone on your¬†team.

  • The latest annual Stack Overflow survey is now open ‚Äì check it out if you want to increase Go's representation in the results¬†:-)

Three Cool slog.Logger Tricks ‚Äî Make slog.Logger sing with a few smart, composable logging¬†patterns.

Joeson Huang

Simpler Backoff ‚Äî Exponential backoff algorithms can be complex and difficult to reason about, or you can use a lookup table to make it¬†trivial.

Josh Bleecher Snyder

üìÑ The Perils of Pointers in the Land of the Zero-Sized Type ‚Äì Pointergeist is definitely my favorite word of the¬†day. Fillmore Labs

üì∫ Making a Game in Go with No Experience ‚Äì Interesting to see someone totally new to Go leap in and use Ebitengine to produce results¬†quickly. Goodgis

üìÑ Let's Write a JSON Parser from Scratch Sushant Dhiman

üìÑ Cross-Compiling C and Go via cgo with Bazel Uros Popovic

üõ† Code & Tools

Bob 0.35: SQL Query Builder and ORM/Factory Generator ‚Äî Though v0.36 and v0.37 have come out in just the past few days, v0.35 was a big milestone for Bob as it enabled the creation of code for SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE queries for Postgres, MySQL and SQLite. Numerous other improvements demand you give it another look too, though ‚Äì some examples¬†here.

Stephen Afam-Osemene

üí° You might also find Bob vs GORM a useful¬†comparison (there are also comparisons with Ent, SQLBoiler, and Jet over on the¬†left).

franz-go: A Complete Apache Kafka Client Library ‚Äî A library that ‚Äúaims to provide every Kafka feature from Apache Kafka v0.8.0 onward‚Äù and certainly has a striking¬†featureset.

Travis Bischel

httpgrace: A net/http Wrapper with Graceful Shutdown ‚Äî Rather than call http.ListenAndServe, the idea is you can call httpgrace.ListenAndServe and get graceful shutdown baked¬†in.

Enrico Candino

  • MCP Go 0.31 ‚Äì An implementation of the Model Context Protocol¬†(MCP).

  • Revive 1.10 ‚Äì Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter for¬†Go.

  • dae 1.0 ‚Äì High-performance eBPF-based transparent¬†proxy.

  • FrankenPHP 1.7 ‚Äì Modern Go-powered PHP app¬†server.

  • Air 1.62 ‚Äì Live reload for Go apps.

  • pdfcpu 0.11 ‚Äì Go PDF¬†processor.

‚≠ê A golden oldie..

go-binsize-treemap: Render a Visualization of Go Executable Space Usage ‚Äî Easier to look at than explain in writing! It‚Äôs a tool that generates an SVG treemap of how the space inside a Go-built executable is used. Even when it's not useful, it's fun to look¬†at.

Nikolay Dubina

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>
UNSUB |¬†¬† WebÁâàÊú¨

üñäÔ∏èÊàëÊú¨Âë®Êú¨Êù•Ë¶ÅÊóÖË°å„ÄÇÊàëÁöÑËÆ°ÂàíÊîπÂèò‰∫ÜÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÊàëÂ∑≤ÁªèËÆ°Âàí‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ËæÉÁü≠ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ËøôÊ¨°ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êõ¥Âø´ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ‰∏ãÂë®ËøîÂõûÂÖ®È¢ùÊúçÂä°ÔºÅ
__
peter CooperÔºåÊÇ®ÁöÑÁºñËæë

‚ÄúÂú®ÂèØÈ¢ÑËßÅÁöÑÊú™Êù•ÔºåGOÂõ¢ÈòüÂ∞ÜÂÅúÊ≠¢ËøΩÊ±ÇÂè•Ê≥ïËØ≠Ë®ÄÊõ¥Êîπ‰ª•ËøõË°åÈîôËØØÂ§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ËøòÂ∞ÜÂÖ≥Èó≠ÊâÄÊúâÂºÄÊîæÂíå‰º†ÂÖ•ÁöÑÂª∫ËÆÆÔºåËøô‰∫õÂª∫ËÆÆ‰∏ªË¶ÅÊ∂âÂèäÈîôËØØÂ§ÑÁêÜËØ≠Ê≥ïÔºåËÄåÊó†ÈúÄËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Ë∞ÉÊü•„ÄÇ‚Äù

>

___
Robert GriesemerÂíåGo Team

[| no]ÂØπÈîôËØØÂ§ÑÁêÜ - Â§ÑÁêÜÈîôËØØÁöÑ‰∏ªÈ¢òÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊîπÂñÑÂõ¥ÁªïËøôÊ†∑ÂÅöÁöÑËØ≠Ê≥ïÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂ§öÂπ¥Êù•ÔºåÂ§öÂπ¥Êù•Â∑≤ÁªèÊèêÂá∫‰∫ÜÂæàÂ§öÔºå‰ΩÜÊúâÊó∂ÂÄºÂæó‰∏ÄÊèêÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂú®ÂÖ∂‰ªñÂú∞ÊñπÂíåÂÖ∂‰ªñÊñπÈù¢ÁöÑËåÉÂõ¥ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ÂàíÂàÜ„ÄÇÁé∞Áä∂„ÄÇ

ÁΩó‰ºØÁâπ¬∑Ê†ºÈáåÂ°ûÈªòÔºàRobert GriesemerÔºâ

- Âú®KubernetesÂü∫Á°ÄÊû∂ÊûÑÁÆ°ÁêÜÊñπÈù¢Ê≠£Âú®Âä™ÂäõËß£ÂÜ≥‚ÄúÊûÑÂª∫‰∏é‰π∞ÂÖ•‚ÄùÂÜ≥ÂÆöÔºü‰Ω†Âπ∂‰∏çÂ≠§ÂçïÔºÅ‰∏ãËΩΩÊåáÂçóÔºå‰ª•ÂèëÁé∞ÊØèÁßçÊñπÊ≥ïÁöÑÂà©ÂºäÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Êàë‰ª¨ÂàÜËß£‰∫ÜÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ÔºåÈ£éÈô©ÂíåROI„ÄÇ Á´ãÂç≥Ëé∑ÂèñÔºÅ

fairwinds

- GO 1.23ÂºïÂÖ•‰∫ÜËá™ÂÆö‰πâËø≠‰ª£Âô®Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØÊ†áÂáÜÁöÑ‚Äú‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊÄß‚Äù‰∏é‰∏çÂàÜÁ±ªÂèØËÉΩ‰ºö‰ª§‰∫∫Âõ∞ÊÉë„ÄÇËøôÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÊèêÂá∫‰∫ÜÊõ¥Ê∏ÖÊô∞ÁöÑÁ∫Ø‰∏é‰∏çÁ∫ØÂáÄÁöÑÂå∫Âà´ÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂÆû‰æãÂíåÁª©ÊïàËßÅËß£„ÄÇ

Julien Cretel

item.title: „ÄêGo 1.25 Release Candidate 1 released„ÄëÈÄâÊã©1.25ÈáäÊîæÂÄôÈÄâ‰∫∫1ÈáäÊîæ
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã557 ‚Äî June 11, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.25 Release Candidate 1 ‚Äî The final release of Go 1.25 isn‚Äôt till August, but the Go team is confident enough to issue the first RC now. The only language change is the removal of the notion of core types as explained by Robert Griesemer recently. There‚Äôs plenty going on behind the scenes, though, like the new experimental garbage collector and changes to both GOMAXPROCS and the generation of debugging¬†information.

The Go Team

The Draft Go 1.25 Release Notes ‚Äî Go 1.25 RC1 has landed today but the release notes for the final release are already being worked on in advance and make for a handy reference to what you can¬†expect.

The Go Team

Complete Go for Professional Developers ‚Äî Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with Go¬†daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Why I'm Excited About Go for Agents ‚Äî If you view agents as (mostly) stateless tasks running in a loop, then Go‚Äôs concurrency model and use of Context make the language nearly perfect for developing them. Plus, Go‚Äôs excellent profiling story means you‚Äôll be able to chase down any memory or thread¬†leaks.

Alexander Belanger (Hatchet)

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.24.4 and 1.23.1 have been¬†released.

  • GitHub's CodeQL code scanning can now access private dependencies stored in private registries on Go projects.

  • Datadog user? They've released v2.0 of their Go tracer which offers significant¬†improvements.

Modern (Go) Application Design ‚Äî A concise take on organizing applications around data models and use-case¬†boundaries.

Tit Petric

Working with BF16 (bfloat16) in Go on Arm Processors ‚Äî An ARM-focused guide to using low-precision BF16 floats in Go via Cgo or GoAT, despite the lack of native language¬†support.

zhenghaoz

Prevent Postgres Slowdowns on Go Apps with This Check List ‚Äî Avoid regressions in your Go app using this monthly Postgres performance checklist to catch issues¬†early.

pganalyze sponsor

üìÑ You Could Automate (Some) Boilerplate Go Error Handling with a Formatter ‚Äì Thoughts inspired by the recent announcement on error handling syntax by the Go¬†team. Chris Siebenmann

üìÑ The Ingredients of a Productive Monorepo Sean Gillespie

üõ† Code & Tools

go-redis 9.10: The Official Redis Client for Go ‚Äî A significant release for one big reason. Redis 8.0 was recently released and as well as becoming open source again, the popular data structure store now supports vector sets and vector similiarity search. My experiments with this feature have been very promising and go-redis now has experimental support for vector sets too. Main docs¬†site.

Various Contributors

GoAT: A Go Assembly Transpiler for C ‚Äî A tool designed to take C functions and transpile them into Go assembly¬†code.

zhenghaoz

tinygo-tkey: Develop Go Apps for the Tillitis TKey-1 ‚Äî The TKey is a new, open-source USB security token device and Ron (of TinyGo fame) has created a way to run Go-built apps on¬†it.

Ron Evans

Raylib-Go-Wasm: Raylib Go Bindings for the Web ‚Äî Raylib offers an easy way to create videogames, including from Go, but its Go bindings haven‚Äôt supported Go‚Äôs abilities to target the Web platform till now (like Ebitengine, say, does). It‚Äôs still in its early stages and the author wants help and feedback, but some readers are sure to find this¬†useful.

Omer

  • GoReleaser v2.10 ‚Äì The popular app release tool has a major improvement in Homebrew Cask creation, plus an experimental MCP server to enable AI agents to use it¬†directly.

  • asdf 0.18 ‚Äì Extendable version manager with support for numerous developer tool¬†ecosystems.

  • gRPC-Go 1.73 ‚Äì Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 based¬†RPC.

  • Permify 1.4 ‚Äì Google Zanzibar-inspired¬†authorization.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Outpost: Open source infrastructure for outbound webhooks and event delivery to RabbitMQ, SQS, Kinesis, etc.¬†(https://github.com/hookdeck/outpost)

üß† Discern is hiring a senior full-stack Go/React dev to help automate entity compliance (US/LATAM). Join us:¬†https://wellfound.com/l/2zxcz1

üîé And one for fun..

NoxDir: Terminal Utility for Visualizing File System Usage ‚Äî A well-presented, Go-powered cross-platform CLI tool for visualizing and exploring file system usage. It makes good use of Charm‚Äôs popular Bubble Tea for its attractive¬†presentation.

crumbyte

üí° gdu is another popular choice in this space that remains well¬†maintained.

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>
unsub |¬†¬† WebÁâàÊú¨

üõ†‰ª£Á†ÅÂíåÂ∑•ÂÖ∑

- Âá∫‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈáçÂ§ßÂéüÂõ†ÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇ redis 8.0 ÊúÄËøëÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÔºåÊµÅË°åÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÁªìÊûÑÂ≠òÂÇ®Áé∞Âú®ÊîØÊåÅÂêëÈáèÈõÜÂíåÂêëÈáèÁõ∏‰ººÊÄßÊêúÁ¥¢„ÄÇÊàëÂØπÊ≠§ÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂÆûÈ™åÈùûÂ∏∏ÊúâÂâçÈÄîÔºåËÄåGo-RedisÁé∞Âú®‰πüÂØπÂêëÈáèÈõÜÊúâÂÆûÈ™åÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇ Main Docs Site„ÄÇ

ÂêÑÁßçË¥°ÁåÆËÄÖ

- ‰∏ÄÁßçÊó®Âú®ÈááÁî®CÂäüËÉΩÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ËΩ¨Êç¢‰∏∫ Zhenghaoz

- tinygo fameÔºâÂàõÂª∫‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁßçÂú®ÂÖ∂‰∏äËøêË°ågo poy poguilt poguilt poguilt of toÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÇ

ÁΩóÊÅ©¬∑ÂüÉÊñáÊñØÔºàRon EvansÔºâ

‚Äî Raylib offers an easy way to create videogames, including from Go, but its Go bindings haven‚Äôt supported Go‚Äôs abilities to target the Web platform till now (like ebitengine ÔºåËØ¥ÔºåÂÅöÔºâ„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ªçÂ§Ñ‰∫éÊó©ÊúüÈò∂ÊÆµÔºå‰ΩúËÄÖÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∏ÆÂä©ÂíåÂèçÈ¶àÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÊúâ‰∫õËØªËÄÖ‰∏ÄÂÆö‰ºöÂèëÁé∞ËøôÂæàÊúâÁî®„ÄÇ

omer

  • ASDF 0.18 - ÂèØÊâ©Â±ïÁâàÊú¨ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂô®ÔºåÂπ∂ÊîØÊåÅ‰ºóÂ§öÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁîüÊÄÅÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ

üì∞ÂàÜÁ±ª

ÂâçÊèêÔºöÂá∫Á´ôWebhooksÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÂü∫Á°ÄÊû∂ÊûÑÂíå‰∫ã‰ª∂‰∫§‰ªòÁªôRabbitMQÔºåSQSÔºåKinesisÁ≠â„ÄÇ ÔºÅ

üß†DISCENTÊ≠£Âú®ÈõáÁî®È´òÁ∫ßÂÖ®Ê†àGO/RECT DEVÔºå‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©Ëá™Âä®ÂåñÂÆû‰ΩìÂêàËßÑÊÄßÔºàUS/LATAMÔºâ„ÄÇÂä†ÂÖ•Êàë‰ª¨Ôºö

item.title: „ÄêGo in the Google I/O spotlight„ÄëËøõÂÖ•Google I/O Spotlight
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã555 ‚Äî May 28, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

‚ñ∂¬†¬†What's New in Go: Google's Take ‚Äî Released as part of last week‚Äôs Google I/O, Go‚Äôs project lead and lead devrel team up to present an extensive list of recent additions and improvements to Go. It‚Äôs good to see Google presenting an official roundup and there‚Äôs more depth in 20 minutes than you might expect (though you can skip the first few minutes which is essentially a pitch for the¬†language).

Google

2x-40x Faster Docker Builds with Blacksmith ‚Äî With a one-line code change, Blacksmith can make your Docker builds incremental by mounting your Docker layer cache into your GitHub Actions runner. Blacksmith is used by 600+ companies like Ashby, Clerk, and¬†Mintlify.

Blacksmith sponsor

The Results of Go's Cryptography Security Audit ‚Äî The core team brought in an external security firm to audit Go‚Äôs cryptography packages, resulting in a single low-severity issue in an unsupported integration (fixed in Go 1.24) and various other findings. The team also explains some other security enhancements coming to Go¬†soon.

Roland Shoemaker and Filippo Valsorda

IN BRIEF:

  • John Reilly reflects on the recent adoption of Go for reimplementing TypeScript in a native manner and why Go is 'the pragmatic choice' of¬†language.

  • The Go-powered FrankenPHP PHP application server is now officially supported by the PHP Foundation.

  • A developer put seven languages (including Go) under a heavy stress test to see how they'd cope. Go 'performed admirably' but its GC eventually fell¬†behind.

Solving Flaky Tests with Go 1.24's synctest ‚Äî Goroutine scheduling can introduce hard-to-debug complexity to tests, but Go 1.24‚Äôs synctest package can make it easier to test concurrent code by introducing isolated ‚Äòbubbles‚Äô to keep things coordinated and more¬†deterministic.

Phuong Le

The Generics Way to Use GORM ‚Äî GORM is a popular ORM library for Go and its latest release (v1.30.0) has added support for using generics. This post shows off the¬†benefits.

Jinzhu

CodeRabbit‚Äôs Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf ‚Äî AI code reviews in VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf: line-by-line checks, one-click fixes & code-aware feedback - free in your IDE. Install¬†now.

CodeRabbit sponsor

üìÑ Taking More Control Over Your Cobra CLI Documentation ‚Äì A tip for those using the Cobra CLI¬†framework. Jamie Tanna

üìÑ Another Tale of go.mod Bloat Ted Unangst

üìÑ Working with JSON Web Tokens in Go Alex Pliutau

üì∫ Coding a MySQL Database Proxy for Fun Package Main

üì∫ Building a Minesweeper Game with Go and Raylib Package Main

üìÑ An Experiment in Using Git as S3 Kris Tun

üõ† Code & Tools

chafa-go: Render Images in the Terminal with Chafa ‚Äî Go bindings for Chafa, a C library that uses smart combinations of Unicode symbols to render graphics in terminal environments (or pass images through to terminal emulators with direct image rendering abilities). It uses purego to avoid needing CGO but does need Go¬†1.24.

Konstantinos Artopoulos

FSBroker: Broker, Group, Dedup, and Filter FSNotify Events ‚Äî A library that sits on top of fsnotify (which works cross-platform) and converts raw file system events into a more usable¬†form.

Hazem Elshabini

godump: A Pretty-Printer and Debug Dumper for Structs ‚Äî Inspired by a similar feature in Laravel, this library lets you print structs, slices, maps, and more, in an easy to read fashion at the¬†terminal.

Chris Miles

vipsgen: Go Binding Generator for libvips ‚Äî libvps is a popular and efficient image processing library. vipsgen lets you generate Go bindings against a libvips install that are type-safe, robust, and fully¬†documented.

Adrian Shum

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Course: Complete Go for Professional Developers ‚Äî Craft production-grade APIs with Go. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with Go daily.

  • TableWriter 1.0.7 ‚Äì Render rich text tables in ASCII, Unicode, Markdown, and at the¬†terminal¬†(see above).

  • Gnet v2.8 ‚Äì High-perf, non-blocking event loop networking¬†library.

  • Joker 1.5 ‚Äì A small Clojure interpreter and¬†linter.

  • go-redis 9.9 ‚Äì Official Go Redis client¬†library.

  • webdav 5.8 ‚Äì Standalone WebDAV¬†server.

  • Roaring 2.5 ‚Äì Roaring bitmaps for Go.

üïπÔ∏è And one for fun..

Night Knight: A 60 FPS Go Remake of an 80's Videogame ‚Äî A reader and their partner made an Ebitengine powered retro game, converted from a game originally on the 1980‚Äôs MSX home computer. It‚Äôs available to download for Windows¬†only.

Anca and Claus

üòÖ I've been 'vibe coding' my own Go 3D game too ‚Äì it's been a lot of fun and definitely a learning¬†experience..

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>
unsub |¬†¬† webÁâàÊú¨

üõ†‰ª£Á†ÅÂíåÂ∑•ÂÖ∑
1.48em;> 1.48em;

- chafa Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÂÖ∏ÂûãÁöÑÂõæÂÉèÁªàÁ´ØÂõæÂÉèÔºàÊàñ‰ΩøÁî®ÂõæÂÉè‰∏≠ÁöÑÂõæÂÉèÔºâÔºàÊàñÔºâÂõæÂÉèÁ´ØÂè£ÔºàÊàñÔºâÂõæÂÉèÁ´ØÂè£ÔºàÊàñËÉΩÂäõÔºâ„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ΩøÁî® purego IDÈúÄË¶ÅCGOÔºå‰ΩÜÁ°ÆÂÆûÈúÄË¶ÅËøõË°å1.24„ÄÇ

konstantinos artopoulos

- ‰Ωç‰∫é fsnotify wher cross-platformÔºâÁöÑÂ∫ì‰∏≠ fors-platform

Hazem Elshabini

- ÂèóLaravel‰∏≠ÁöÑÁ±ª‰ººÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂêØÂèëÔºåËØ•Â∫ìÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©ÊÇ®‰ª•Êòì‰∫éÈòÖËØªÁöÑÊñπÂºèÊâìÂç∞ÁªìÊûÑÔºåÂàáÁâáÔºåÂú∞ÂõæÁ≠â„ÄÇ

item.title: „ÄêIan Lance Taylor takes a break from Go„Äë‰ºäÊÅ©¬∑ÂÖ∞ÊñØ¬∑Ê≥∞ÂãíÔºàIan Lance TaylorÔºâ‰ºëÊÅØ‰∏Ä‰∏ã
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã554 ‚Äî May 14, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

üñäÔ∏è I'm going to Google I/O next week, so Go Weekly will be taking a break and will return on May 28. If you happen to be at I/O too, say hi if you see an Englishman rambling on about¬†newsletters. I'm intrigued to see if Go gets any presence¬†there.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

Ian Lance Taylor Has Left Google ‚Äî One of the most active contributors to Go (and the initial creator of the Go frontend for GCC) has left Google and, in turn, the Go project, though he hopes to return as a contributor one day. As a commenter on the related Hacker News thread (which is packed with all sorts of conjecture) said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to overstate the amount of service Ian provided to the Go¬†community‚Äù

Ian Lance Taylor

New Experimental 'Green Tea' Garbage Collector ‚Äî A proposal outlining a new span-based, ‚Äúmemory-aware‚Äù GC algorithm focused on small objects that improves spatial and temporal locality on modern multi-CPU systems by better exploiting memory topologies and cache hierarchies. Benchmarks are mixed, but it‚Äôs early days. You can try it out today with gotip and it‚Äôs slated to be an opt-in experiment in Go¬†1.25.

Knyszek and Clements

Complete Go for Professional Developers ‚Äî Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with Go¬†daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Which Go Router Should I Use? ‚Äî Alex looks at some popular routing options, citing the pros and cons of each and wrapping it up with a nice decision flowchart and a list of other routing options. We‚Äôve linked to this before but he‚Äôs updated it for¬†2025.

Alex Edwards

IN BRIEF:

  • üá¨üáß GopherCon UK takes place this August but its CFP closes this Saturday.

  • ü¶ã If you use Bluesky at all, someone's put together a 'starter pack' of Go contributors you can follow there.

Centralize HTTP Error Handling in Go ‚Äî A nice pattern to clean up your HTTP handlers by creating a custom error and wrapper¬†function.

Alexis Bouchez

üìÑ Using the OpenAI Responses API in Go ‚Äì A full walkthrough for OpenAI‚Äôs latest way to interact with its¬†LLMs. Chris Sotherden

üìÑ Monitoring a Go App with Prometheus and Grafana Pradumna Saraf and Docker

üìÑ sync.WaitGroup: Powerful, but Tricky.. Jens Neuse

üõ† Code & Tools

pdfcpu: A PDF Processing and Manipulation Library ‚Äî You can validate and optimize PDFs, split them, merge PDFs together, extract elements, and more. The latest version adds support for digital signature validation and improved image handling. GitHub¬†repo.

pdfcpu

Outpost: Outbound Webhooks and Event Destinations Infrastructure ‚Äî A way to add reliable outbound webhooks and events to your apps with support for destination types such as Amazon EventBridge, AWS SQS, AWS SNS, GCP Pub/Sub, RabbitMQ, and¬†Kafka.

Hookdeck

Go Panicked Again? Yeah, Sentry Saw It‚Äîand Kept the Receipts ‚Äî Goroutines are great‚Äîuntil one quietly dies. Sentry catches panics, traces them back, and gives you full context. üëâ Try it free before your next deploy gets¬†weird.

Sentry sponsor

Fx 36.0: A Command-Line JSON Processing Tool ‚Äî If you‚Äôve got some files full of JSON that you want to slice and dice, Fx is for you. Notably, v36 adds support for streaming JSON and tailing such streams, it‚Äôs also much faster and less memory hungry when parsing the largest of JSON files. A solid update for a very handy¬†tool.

Anton Medvedev

Goldmark: A Markdown Parser Written in Go ‚Äî Pure Go, easy to extend, and CommonMark compliant (which GitHub-Flavored Markdown is based upon). There‚Äôs also a WebAssembly powered Goldmark playground you can¬†try.

Yusuke Inuzuka

Compress: Optimized Compression Packages for Go ‚Äî Covers a variety of compression standards like zstandard, S2, gzip, snappy, and¬†zip.

Klaus Post

UPX 5.0: The 'Ultimate Packer' for EXecutables ‚Äî Staying on the theme of compression.. UPX is a tool that adds run-time compression and decompression to executables to reduce their size. It‚Äôs not Go specific but can work on Go executables as Ben Boyter discovered back in¬†2019.

Oberhumer, Molnar, and Reiser

  • üìä go-echarts 2.5.4 ‚Äì Charting and data visualization library that uses Apache¬†ECharts. You can see examples in the¬†docs.

  • FerretDB 2.2 ‚Äì A database that acts like MongoDB but uses Postgres for¬†storage.

  • go-github 72.0 ‚Äì Go client library for accessing the GitHub API¬†v3.

  • pgroll 0.12 ‚Äì Zero-downtime, reversible schema migrations for¬†Postgres.

  • purego 0.8.3 ‚Äì Library for calling C functions from Go without Cgo.

  • Buf 1.54 ‚Äì CLI tool for working with Protocol¬†Buffers.

  • ü§ñ Go OpenAI 1.40 ‚Äì An OpenAI API wrapper¬†library.

üòé Did You Know..?

As much as we enjoy making this newsletter, we also publish a handful of others you might not know about. You can see the latest issues of them all directly on their¬†homepages:

üíé Ruby Weekly was our first ever newsletter, and it's still going strong 749 issues later! Unsurprisingly it's for Ruby and Rails enthusiasts.

üíõ JavaScript Weekly covers all things JavaScript, but also the JS ecosystem more broadly, including TypeScript, WebAssembly, Vue.js, build tools, and¬†Svelte.

‚öõÔ∏è Just round the corner from JS is React Status covering, unsurprisingly, the React world and Node Weekly which goes deeper into Node.js, the npm ecosystem, and other server-side JS runtimes like Deno and¬†Bun.

üë©‚Äçüíª Frontend Focus covers everything that appears browser-side! CSS, HTML, accessibility, WebGPU, browser updates ‚Äì it's all in there.

üêò Last, but not least, Postgres Weekly rounds out the family. It's the smallest newsletter, but always packed with great stuff as the Postgres ecosystem punches above its weight in terms of news and interesting¬†releases.

__
Peter Cooper, your editor

„Äë
